class="css-sklrp3"><div class="css-1u5onbp epjyd6m1"><div class="css-165eim7 ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/tara-parker-pope" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Tara dateTime="2022-01-28T17:12:01-05:00" class="css-ld3wwf e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Published <!-- -->Jan. 14, 2022</span><span class="css-233int e16638kd4">Updated <!-- -->Jan. 28, 2022</span></time></li></ul></div><div class="css-tk9fsr"><a class="css-1d32glx" href="https://www.nytimes.com/es/2022/01/17/espanol/n95-covid-mascarillas.html" data-version="es" title="Read in Spanish">Leer en español</a></div></div></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The fast-spread of the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/article/omicron-coronavirus-variant.html" title="">infectious Omicron variant</a> has prompted many people to try to upgrade to a higher-quality mask. But that’s easier said than done.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Anyone who has shopped for a mask online or in stores has discovered a dizzying array in a variety of shapes, sizes and colors. Knowing which mask to pick and making sure it’s not a counterfeit requires the sleuthing skills of a forensic investigator. And once you choose one, it’s still a gamble; many people discover they’ve ordered a mask that’s too big or too small for their face or just doesn’t fit right.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“No one has made this easy, that’s for sure,” said Bill Taubner, president of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://bonafidemasks.com/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Bona Fide Masks</a>, the exclusive distributor in the United States for both Powecom and Harley KN95 masks, which are from China. “A lot of people end up doing a lot of research.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Unlike cloth masks, high-quality masks — called N95s, KN95s and KF94s — are made with layers of high-tech filtering material that trap at least 94 to 95 percent of the most risky particles. Under a microscope, the filters look like dense forests of tangled fibers that capture even the hardest-to-trap particles that can bounce around and escape the fibers of cloth masks. High-grade masks also have an electrostatically charged filter that helps attract and trap particles.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Early in the pandemic, high-quality medical and respirator-style masks were in short supply. Now the problem is there are so many different masks for sale, it’s tough to know which ones have been tested and certified by government agencies, and which are counterfeit. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/npptl/respirators/testing/NonNIOSHresults.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Testing studies</a> have found that many counterfeit masks don’t even offer the same level of protection as a cloth mask. We interviewed mask manufacturers, importers, public health officials and independent researchers for advice on choosing a quality mask. Here’s a guide.</p><h2 class="css-ow6j0y eoo0vm40" id="link-26dfd18">Choose your mask style.</h2><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Masks come in different shapes and sizes. You’ll find “cup” style masks, “duck bill” masks and “flat-fold” masks. The best mask is the one that fits snugly against your face and is comfortable. Start by ordering in small quantities and try different styles to find the best one for your face. Many masks are described as “one size fits most.” But some come in small or larger sizes. “You’re not getting the full benefit of a respirator if you put it on and it’s not forming a seal to your face,” said Nicole Vars McCullough, vice president for personal safety at the 3M Company, the largest U.S. manufacturer of N95 masks.</p><h3 class="css-x75iqs e1gnsphs0" id="link-5a1d3deb"><span>N95 respirator</span></h3></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-1l3p632 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><picture><source media="(max-width: 599px) and (min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),(max-width: 599px) and srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2022/02/13/well/13well-n95mask-guide0/13well-n95mask-guide0-mobileMasterAt3x.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale&width=1800"/><img alt="In most situations, you don’t need to throw out your disposable mask after each use." class="css-r3fift" (min-width: 1005px) 60vw, 100vw" decoding="async" width="600" height="400"/></picture></div><figcaption class="css-1l44abu ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">In most situations, you don’t need to throw out your disposable mask after each use.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Sarah Kobos/Wirecutter</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">N95</strong> respirator mask is regulated by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), a division of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Almost all N95 masks use head straps — two elastic bands that wrap behind the head. If a mask claiming to be an N95 has ear loops, it’s most likely a fake. The C.D.C. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/docs/2021-124/pdfs/2021-124.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">has a guide</a> for spotting fake N95s.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h3 class="css-x75iqs e1gnsphs0" id="link-2995f6a7"><span>KN95 respirator</span></h3></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-1l3p632 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1l44abu ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">4CAir AireTrust Nano mask.</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Sarah Kobos/Wirecutter</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">KN95</strong> is similar to the N95, but it has ear loops and is made to meet Chinese standards for medical masks. Some people prefer them for comfort, and because they come in smaller sizes. While you can find legitimate KN95 masks, the supply chain is riddled with counterfeits and there’s little regulation or oversight of the product. One study found that <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/types-of-masks.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">60 percent of the supply of KN95s</a> in the United States are counterfeit. Keep reading for ways to spot them.</p><h3 class="css-x75iqs e1gnsphs0" id="link-18601"><span>KF94</span></h3></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-1l3p632 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1l44abu ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">Kyungin Flax KF94</span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Sarah Kobos/Wirecutter</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The <strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">KF94</strong> is a high-quality mask that folds flat and is made in Korea. It is designed specifically for the consumer market. The KF stands for “Korean filter,” and the 94 means it filters 94 percent of particles. The masks are heavily regulated in Korea, which lowers the risk of counterfeits. However, some fake masks made in China may be labeled KF94, so shoppers still need to do their homework.</p><div role="complementary" aria-labelledby="storyline-latest-updates" class="css-1nfx0ef"><div class="css-8atqhb"><h2 id="storyline-latest-updates" class="css-lpqacv"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/04/06/world/covid-19-mandates-cases-vaccine">The Coronavirus Pandemic: Latest Updates</a></h2><div class="css-rchdvv"><time class="css-101kej7" dateTime="2022-04-06T14:05:07.794Z"><span>Updated </span><div class="css-ki347z"><span class="css-1stvlmo">April 6, 2022, 10:05 a.m. ET</span><span class="css-kpxlkr"></span></div></time><span class="css-1dv1kvn" aria-live="polite"></span></div><ul class="css-15zvb7e"><li class="css-1l8wklm"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/04/06/world/covid-19-mandates-cases-vaccine#the-morning-newsletter-explores-why-us-cases-have-not-yet-started-rising-again">The Morning newsletter explores why U.S. cases have not yet started rising again.</a></li><li class="css-1l8wklm"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/04/06/world/covid-19-mandates-cases-vaccine#greece-fire-covid-ward">Fire and smoke at a Covid ward in Greece kill one and injure at least two others.</a></li><li class="css-1l8wklm"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2022/04/06/world/covid-19-mandates-cases-vaccine#big-banks-are-offering-flexible-work-arrangements-as-they-chase-talent-that-would-rather-stay-home">Big banks are offering flexible work arrangements as they chase talent that would rather stay home.</a></li></ul><div class="styln-survey-component" id="storyline-survey-latest-updates"></div></div></div><h3 class="css-x75iqs e1gnsphs0" id="link-50b0e86e"><span>Masks for children</span></h3><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The mask market is particularly tricky for parents trying to find masks for children. No N95 mask has been approved for children, so any mask that claims to be an N95 for kids is a fake. However, N95s do come in S/M sizes that might work for some older children. KN95 and KF94 masks have styles made for children, so once you find one, you need to go through the same vetting process that you would use for an adult mask, using the links below.</p><h2 class="css-ow6j0y eoo0vm40" id="link-73d4c651">Buy from a reputable supplier.</h2><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Big retailers like Home Depot and Lowes typically work directly with manufacturers approved by NIOSH or their distributors, so if you find an N95 mask in a major retail store you can be confident you’re getting the real thing. It’s a good idea to check manufacturer websites to see where they sell their products and who their authorized distributors are, Dr. McCullough said. 3M has a dedicated spot on its website to help <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.3m.com/3M/en_US/worker-health-safety-us/covid19/covid-fraud/?utm_medium=redirect&utm_source=vanity-url&utm_campaign=3m.com/covidfraud" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">consumers spot fake masks.</a></p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Finding a reliable mask on Amazon is trickier because you’ll see legitimate masks mixed in with counterfeits, although the differences won’t always be obvious. If you must use Amazon, try to shop directly in the on-site stores of mask makers like <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.amazon.com/stores/3M+Personal+Protective+Equipment/page/D9E33F3B-99C9-471A-9713-580D0CC74FF9?ref_=ast_bln" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">3M</a> or <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.amazon.com/stores/node/2594826011?_encoding=UTF8&field-lbr_brands_browse-bin=Kimberly-Clark%20Professional&ref_=bl_dp_s_web_2594826011" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Kimberly-Clark</a>. (You can usually find a link to a maker’s online store right below a product name.)</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">If you’re buying a KF94 on Amazon, look closely at the packaging to make sure it’s made in Korea and includes the required labeling (see below for more details). Aaron Collins, an engineer who routinely tests masks and who has gained a <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/user/coll0412" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">YouTube following</a> as “Mask Nerd,” recommends buying KF94s from Korean beauty product importers like <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://behealthyusa.net/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Be Healthy</a> or <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://kmact.com/products/dr-puri-kf94-mask-for-adult" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">KMact</a>. Once you learn the names of a few KF94 manufacturers, you can try to find their websites to learn where they are sold. For instance, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="http://happylifekorea.com/eng/index.php" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Happy Life</a> lists its five U.S. distributors on its home page.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">You can sometimes find N95 and KN95 masks for sale directly on the website of a mask maker, <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://shop.demetech.us/products/n95-respirator-masks-fold-style?variant=40938094297264" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">like Demetech</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.armbrustusa.com/collections" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Armbrust USA</a>. You can also look for companies that are exclusive distributors of KN95 masks, like <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://bonafidemasks.com/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Bona Fide Masks</a>. The nonprofit site <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.projectn95.org/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Project N95</a> is also a reliable place to shop. Many trusted sites are overwhelmed by demand right now, so you may encounter delays in fulfillment and shipping times.</p><h2 class="css-ow6j0y eoo0vm40" id="link-50c99808">Check labels and printing.</h2><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Legitimate N95s and KN95s are required to have specific text stamped on the front of the mask. Although you may find one in a fun color, masks that are printed with fancy designs or don’t have text stamped on them are probably fake.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Your N95 should be stamped with “NIOSH,” as well as the company name, the model and lot numbers, and something called a “TC approval” number, which can be used to look up the mask on a list of approved ones. The C.D.C. has <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/npptl/pdfs/N95-Infographic-Mask-Labeling-508.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">created an infographic</a> showing you the printing to look for on your N95.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-3mi1lt e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-zjzyr8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:535.5333333333333px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1l44abu ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="true" class="css-16f3y1r e13ogyst0">KN95 and N95 masks are required to have specific text stamped on the front. </span><span class="css-cnj6d5 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Charlie Rubin for The New York Times</span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">A legitimate KN95 should also be stamped with text, including the name of the manufacturer, the model, and “GB2626-2019,” which is a reference to a quality control standard approved by the Chinese government. (If your mask has a GB number that ends in 2006, which is a previous standard, just check the expiration date.)</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">The KF94 won’t be stamped with text, but the package should say “Made in Korea” and include the product name, manufacturer and distributor name. Each mask should be packaged individually in a flat, glossy rectangular wrapper with a textured border. The package will also have an expiration date and a lot number printed on it. (Masks that carry an electrostatic charge all have expiration dates.) If your mask comes from a Korean importer, the information on the package will be in Korean, but many companies have begun to create English-language packaging.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><h2 class="css-ow6j0y eoo0vm40" id="link-995e9b3">Use trusted sources.</h2><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">A number of resources have sprung up to help people navigate the mask-buying process. <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://shop.projectn95.org/masks/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Project N95</a> is a nonprofit known for vetting its mask suppliers. Mr. Collins, the Mask Nerd, has created a number of lists and resources for mask buyers. You can check out his <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://twitter.com/masknerd" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Twitter feed</a>, his <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC3fF_rzkmZD0ufN685YE7lg" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">YouTube channel</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1M0mdNLpTWEGcluK6hh5LjjcFixwmOG853Ff45d3O-L0/htmlview?usp=drive_web&ouid=108355114845682180386&pru=AAABfniWips*ZW4K5ipiMBIUEgzyHDB1eA" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">a spreadsheet</a> he has created of nearly 450 different masks and how they performed in his tests.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Mr. Collins may be best known for his list of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1i06OAItoOwIUaMjElr8mhh0Rw-it6WL-ODIQMZUOQxE/edit#gid=0" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">children’s masks</a>. While there is no N95 mask for kids approved in the United States, mask makers in China and Korea have created KN95s and KF94s for children, including some with child-friendly colors and prints. Mr. Collins created <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A88AGnN-nwI" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">a video “primer for parents”</a> about finding a high-quality mask for kids that has more than 100,000 views.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">“I had retired from mask testing,” Mr. Collins said, noting that he doesn’t receive any compensation for his work. “But I came out of retirement to do the kids video. The only place I’ve seen a list of test data is unfortunately me.”</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">Wirecutter, a product review site owned by The New York Times, has a guide <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/reviews/where-to-buy-n95-kn95-masks-online/" title="">for buying quality masks</a>, one for <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/reviews/best-kids-face-masks/" title="">buying children’s masks</a> and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.nytimes.com/wirecutter/blog/12-signs-you-have-a-fake-n95-kn95-or-kf94-mask/" title="">a list of 12 red flags</a> that might signal your mask is a counterfeit.</p><h2 class="css-ow6j0y eoo0vm40" id="link-341060bd">Do your research.</h2><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">It’s not easy, but the C.D.C. has a few lists you can use to confirm a mask has been vetted. A note of caution: If you don’t find a particular mask, make sure you’ve looked it up the correct way, said Anne Miller, executive director of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.projectn95.org/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Project N95</a>. For instance, a Gerson N95 mask won’t be found under the letter “G.” It’s <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/npptl/topics/respirators/disp_part/N95list1sect2-l.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">listed under “L”</a> because the full name of the company that makes it is Louis M. Gerson.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">For N95 masks, go to the C.D.C.’s alphabetical list of <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/npptl/topics/respirators/disp_part/default.html" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">NIOSH-approved respirators</a>. You can also look up the TC approval number using the <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://wwwn.cdc.gov/niosh-cel/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">certified equipment list</a>.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0">For KN95 masks, you can use two checklists from the Food and Drug Administration. The F.D.A. created these lists early in the pandemic, when the agency issued an emergency use authorization that allowed health workers to use KN95 masks because of a shortage of N95s. Now that the N95 supply is adequate, the agency has revoked the authorization for these workers, but other people can still use KN95s. While the list is now a bit outdated, finding your mask on it adds reassurance that it’s less likely to be counterfeit — with the caveat that there’s no longer official U.S. oversight for any of these firms. You’ll need to scroll down to find the list and search box.</p><p class="css-g5piaz evys1bk0"><a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.fda.gov/medical-devices/emergency-use-authorizations-medical-devices/revoked-euas-non-niosh-approved-disposable-filtering-facepiece-respirators#china" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Use this F.D.A. list</a> to find KN95 masks made in China, and <a class="css-1g7m0tk" href="https://www.fda.gov/medical-devices/emergency-use-authorizations-medical-devices/revoked-euas-non-niosh-approved-disposable-filtering-facepiece-respirators#imported" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">this list</a> for KN95 masks made in other countries.</p><p class="css-pncxxs etfikam0">Jin Yu Young<!-- --> contributed to this report.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div></section><div></div><div></div><div></div><div></div><div><div id="bottom-wrapper" class="css-2fttua"><div id="bottom-slug" Under a microscope, the filters look like dense forests of tangled fibers that capture even the hardest-to-trap particles that can bounce around and escape the fibers of cloth masks. High-grade masks also have an electrostatically charged filter that helps attract and trap particles.","formats":[]},"Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlL2ZhYTcxOWVjLWUwMTEtNWU0MC1iNzhkLTJmZTM5Y2FlODdhYQ==":{"__typename":"Article","promotionalHeadline":"How Long Can I Keep Wearing the Same Here’s a guide.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzJmZjU2MmMzLTU3MzktNTg1ZC05YWQzLWZhZWYyMTRkNzQyZA==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.13.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Choose your mask style.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzJmZjU2MmMzLTU3MzktNTg1ZC05YWQzLWZhZWYyMTRkNzQyZA==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.14.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Masks come in different shapes and sizes. You’ll find “cup” style masks, “duck bill” masks and “flat-fold” masks. The best mask is the one that fits snugly against your face and is comfortable. Start by ordering in small quantities and try different styles to find the best one for your face. Many masks are described as “one size fits most.” But some come in small or larger sizes. “You’re not getting the full benefit of a respirator if you put it on and it’s not forming a seal to your face,” said Nicole Vars McCullough, vice president for personal safety at the 3M Company, the largest U.S. manufacturer of N95 masks.","formats":[]},"$Article:QXJ0aWNsZTpueXQ6Ly9hcnRpY2xlLzJmZjU2MmMzLTU3MzktNTg1ZC05YWQzLWZhZWYyMTRkNzQyZA==.sprinkledBody.content@filterEmpty.16.content.0":{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"N95 No N95 mask has been approved for children, so any mask that claims to be an N95 for kids is a fake. However, N95s do come in S\u002FM sizes that might work for some older children. Now that the N95 supply is adequate, the agency has revoked the authorization for these workers, but other people can still use KN95s. While the list is now a bit outdated, finding your mask on it adds reassurance that it’s less likely to be counterfeit — with the caveat that there’s no longer official U.S. oversight for any of these firms. oembed.title: How to Find a Quality Mask (and Avoid Counterfeits)
oembed.summary: Knowing which mask to pick and making sure it’s not a fake requires the sleuthing skills of a forensic investigator. Our guide can help.
oembed.html: <iframe src="https://www.nytimes.com/svc/oembed/html/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2Farticle%2Fcovid-masks.html" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" title="How to Find a Quality Mask (and Avoid Counterfeits)" style="border:none;max-width:500px;min-width:300px;min-height:550px;display:block;width:100%;"></iframe>
oembed.thumbnail_credit: Charlie Rubin for The New York Times

readabilityObject.title: N95, KN95 or KF94? How to Find the Right Covid Mask
readabilityObject.content:
How to Find a Quality Mask (and Avoid Counterfeits)

Knowing which mask to pick and making sure it’s not a fake requires the sleuthing skills of a forensic investigator. Our guide can help.

Credit...Charlie Rubin for The New York Times

  • Published Jan. 14, 2022Updated Jan. 28, 2022

The fast-spread of the infectious Omicron variant has prompted many people to try to upgrade to a higher-quality mask. But that’s easier said than done.

Anyone who has shopped for a mask online or in stores has discovered a dizzying array in a variety of shapes, sizes and colors. Knowing which mask to pick and making sure it’s not a counterfeit requires the sleuthing skills of a forensic investigator. And once you choose one, it’s still a gamble; many people discover they’ve ordered a mask that’s too big or too small for their face or just doesn’t fit right.

“No one has made this easy, that’s for sure,” said Bill Taubner, president of Bona Fide Masks, the exclusive distributor in the United States for both Powecom and Harley KN95 masks, which are from China. “A lot of people end up doing a lot of research.”

Unlike cloth masks, high-quality masks — called N95s, KN95s and KF94s — are made with layers of high-tech filtering material that trap at least 94 to 95 percent of the most risky particles. Under a microscope, the filters look like dense forests of tangled fibers that capture even the hardest-to-trap particles that can bounce around and escape the fibers of cloth masks. High-grade masks also have an electrostatically charged filter that helps attract and trap particles.

Early in the pandemic, high-quality medical and respirator-style masks were in short supply. Now the problem is there are so many different masks for sale, it’s tough to know which ones have been tested and certified by government agencies, and which are counterfeit. Testing studies have found that many counterfeit masks don’t even offer the same level of protection as a cloth mask. We interviewed mask manufacturers, importers, public health officials and independent researchers for advice on choosing a quality mask. Here’s a guide.

Choose your mask style.

Masks come in different shapes and sizes. You’ll find “cup” style masks, “duck bill” masks and “flat-fold” masks. The best mask is the one that fits snugly against your face and is comfortable. Start by ordering in small quantities and try different styles to find the best one for your face. Many masks are described as “one size fits most.” But some come in small or larger sizes. “You’re not getting the full benefit of a respirator if you put it on and it’s not forming a seal to your face,” said Nicole Vars McCullough, vice president for personal safety at the 3M Company, the largest U.S. manufacturer of N95 masks.

N95 respirator

The N95 respirator mask is regulated by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), a division of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Almost all N95 masks use head straps — two elastic bands that wrap behind the head. If a mask claiming to be an N95 has ear loops, it’s most likely a fake. The C.D.C. has a guide for spotting fake N95s.

KN95 respirator

The KN95 is similar to the N95, but it has ear loops and is made to meet Chinese standards for medical masks. Some people prefer them for comfort, and because they come in smaller sizes. While you can find legitimate KN95 masks, the supply chain is riddled with counterfeits and there’s little regulation or oversight of the product. One study found that 60 percent of the supply of KN95s in the United States are counterfeit. Keep reading for ways to spot them.

KF94

The KF94 is a high-quality mask that folds flat and is made in Korea. It is designed specifically for the consumer market. The KF stands for “Korean filter,” and the 94 means it filters 94 percent of particles. The masks are heavily regulated in Korea, which lowers the risk of counterfeits. However, some fake masks made in China may be labeled KF94, so shoppers still need to do their homework.

Masks for children

The mask market is particularly tricky for parents trying to find masks for children. No N95 mask has been approved for children, so any mask that claims to be an N95 for kids is a fake. However, N95s do come in S/M sizes that might work for some older children. KN95 and KF94 masks have styles made for children, so once you find one, you need to go through the same vetting process that you would use for an adult mask, using the links below.

Buy from a reputable supplier.

Big retailers like Home Depot and Lowes typically work directly with manufacturers approved by NIOSH or their distributors, so if you find an N95 mask in a major retail store you can be confident you’re getting the real thing. It’s a good idea to check manufacturer websites to see where they sell their products and who their authorized distributors are, Dr. McCullough said. 3M has a dedicated spot on its website to help consumers spot fake masks.

Finding a reliable mask on Amazon is trickier because you’ll see legitimate masks mixed in with counterfeits, although the differences won’t always be obvious. If you must use Amazon, try to shop directly in the on-site stores of mask makers like 3M or Kimberly-Clark. (You can usually find a link to a maker’s online store right below a product name.)

If you’re buying a KF94 on Amazon, look closely at the packaging to make sure it’s made in Korea and includes the required labeling (see below for more details). Aaron Collins, an engineer who routinely tests masks and who has gained a YouTube following as “Mask Nerd,” recommends buying KF94s from Korean beauty product importers like Be Healthy or KMact. Once you learn the names of a few KF94 manufacturers, you can try to find their websites to learn where they are sold. For instance, Happy Life lists its five U.S. distributors on its home page.

You can sometimes find N95 and KN95 masks for sale directly on the website of a mask maker, like Demetech and Armbrust USA. You can also look for companies that are exclusive distributors of KN95 masks, like Bona Fide Masks. The nonprofit site Project N95 is also a reliable place to shop. Many trusted sites are overwhelmed by demand right now, so you may encounter delays in fulfillment and shipping times.

Check labels and printing.

Legitimate N95s and KN95s are required to have specific text stamped on the front of the mask. Although you may find one in a fun color, masks that are printed with fancy designs or don’t have text stamped on them are probably fake.

Your N95 should be stamped with “NIOSH,” as well as the company name, the model and lot numbers, and something called a “TC approval” number, which can be used to look up the mask on a list of approved ones. The C.D.C. has created an infographic showing you the printing to look for on your N95.

A legitimate KN95 should also be stamped with text, including the name of the manufacturer, the model, and “GB2626-2019,” which is a reference to a quality control standard approved by the Chinese government. (If your mask has a GB number that ends in 2006, which is a previous standard, just check the expiration date.)

The KF94 won’t be stamped with text, but the package should say “Made in Korea” and include the product name, manufacturer and distributor name. Each mask should be packaged individually in a flat, glossy rectangular wrapper with a textured border. The package will also have an expiration date and a lot number printed on it. (Masks that carry an electrostatic charge all have expiration dates.) If your mask comes from a Korean importer, the information on the package will be in Korean, but many companies have begun to create English-language packaging.

Use trusted sources.

A number of resources have sprung up to help people navigate the mask-buying process. Project N95 is a nonprofit known for vetting its mask suppliers. Mr. Collins, the Mask Nerd, has created a number of lists and resources for mask buyers. You can check out his Twitter feed, his YouTube channel and a spreadsheet he has created of nearly 450 different masks and how they performed in his tests.

Mr. Collins may be best known for his list of children’s masks. While there is no N95 mask for kids approved in the United States, mask makers in China and Korea have created KN95s and KF94s for children, including some with child-friendly colors and prints. Mr. Collins created a video “primer for parents” about finding a high-quality mask for kids that has more than 100,000 views.

“I had retired from mask testing,” Mr. Collins said, noting that he doesn’t receive any compensation for his work. “But I came out of retirement to do the kids video. The only place I’ve seen a list of test data is unfortunately me.”

Wirecutter, a product review site owned by The New York Times, has a guide for buying quality masks, one for buying children’s masks and a list of 12 red flags that might signal your mask is a counterfeit.

Do your research.

It’s not easy, but the C.D.C. has a few lists you can use to confirm a mask has been vetted. A note of caution: If you don’t find a particular mask, make sure you’ve looked it up the correct way, said Anne Miller, executive director of Project N95. For instance, a Gerson N95 mask won’t be found under the letter “G.” It’s listed under “L” because the full name of the company that makes it is Louis M. Gerson.

For N95 masks, go to the C.D.C.’s alphabetical list of NIOSH-approved respirators. You can also look up the TC approval number using the certified equipment list.

For KN95 masks, you can use two checklists from the Food and Drug Administration. The F.D.A. created these lists early in the pandemic, when the agency issued an emergency use authorization that allowed health workers to use KN95 masks because of a shortage of N95s. Now that the N95 supply is adequate, the agency has revoked the authorization for these workers, but other people can still use KN95s. While the list is now a bit outdated, finding your mask on it adds reassurance that it’s less likely to be counterfeit — with the caveat that there’s no longer official U.S. oversight for any of these firms. You’ll need to scroll down to find the list and search box.

Use this F.D.A. list to find KN95 masks made in China, and this list for KN95 masks made in other countries.

Jin Yu Young contributed to this report.
readabilityObject.textContent: Credit...Charlie Rubin for The New York TimesHow to Find a Quality Mask (and Avoid Counterfeits)Knowing which mask to pick and making sure it’s not a fake requires the sleuthing skills of a forensic investigator. Our guide can help.Credit...Charlie Rubin for The New York TimesPublished Jan. 14, 2022Updated Jan. 28, 2022The fast-spread of the infectious Omicron variant has prompted many people to try to upgrade to a higher-quality mask. But that’s easier said than done.Anyone who has shopped for a mask online or in stores has discovered a dizzying array in a variety of shapes, sizes and colors. Knowing which mask to pick and making sure it’s not a counterfeit requires the sleuthing skills of a forensic investigator. And once you choose one, it’s still a gamble; many people discover they’ve ordered a mask that’s too big or too small for their face or just doesn’t fit right.“No one has made this easy, that’s for sure,” said Bill Taubner, president of Bona Fide Masks, the exclusive distributor in the United States for both Powecom and Harley KN95 masks, which are from China. “A lot of people end up doing a lot of research.”Unlike cloth masks, high-quality masks — called N95s, KN95s and KF94s — are made with layers of high-tech filtering material that trap at least 94 to 95 percent of the most risky particles. Under a microscope, the filters look like dense forests of tangled fibers that capture even the hardest-to-trap particles that can bounce around and escape the fibers of cloth masks. High-grade masks also have an electrostatically charged filter that helps attract and trap particles.Early in the pandemic, high-quality medical and respirator-style masks were in short supply. Now the problem is there are so many different masks for sale, it’s tough to know which ones have been tested and certified by government agencies, and which are counterfeit. Testing studies have found that many counterfeit masks don’t even offer the same level of protection as a cloth mask. We interviewed mask manufacturers, importers, public health officials and independent researchers for advice on choosing a quality mask. Here’s a guide.Choose your mask style.Masks come in different shapes and sizes. You’ll find “cup” style masks, “duck bill” masks and “flat-fold” masks. The best mask is the one that fits snugly against your face and is comfortable. Start by ordering in small quantities and try different styles to find the best one for your face. Many masks are described as “one size fits most.” But some come in small or larger sizes. “You’re not getting the full benefit of a respirator if you put it on and it’s not forming a seal to your face,” said Nicole Vars McCullough, vice president for personal safety at the 3M Company, the largest U.S. manufacturer of N95 masks.N95 respiratorImageCredit...Sarah Kobos/WirecutterThe N95 respirator mask is regulated by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), a division of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Almost all N95 masks use head straps — two elastic bands that wrap behind the head. If a mask claiming to be an N95 has ear loops, it’s most likely a fake. The C.D.C. has a guide for spotting fake N95s.KN95 respiratorImageCredit...Sarah Kobos/WirecutterThe KN95 is similar to the N95, but it has ear loops and is made to meet Chinese standards for medical masks. Some people prefer them for comfort, and because they come in smaller sizes. While you can find legitimate KN95 masks, the supply chain is riddled with counterfeits and there’s little regulation or oversight of the product. One study found that 60 percent of the supply of KN95s in the United States are counterfeit. Keep reading for ways to spot them.KF94ImageCredit...Sarah Kobos/WirecutterThe KF94 is a high-quality mask that folds flat and is made in Korea. It is designed specifically for the consumer market. The KF stands for “Korean filter,” and the 94 means it filters 94 percent of particles. The masks are heavily regulated in Korea, which lowers the risk of counterfeits. However, some fake masks made in China may be labeled KF94, so shoppers still need to do their homework.Masks for childrenThe mask market is particularly tricky for parents trying to find masks for children. No N95 mask has been approved for children, so any mask that claims to be an N95 for kids is a fake. However, N95s do come in S/M sizes that might work for some older children. KN95 and KF94 masks have styles made for children, so once you find one, you need to go through the same vetting process that you would use for an adult mask, using the links below.Buy from a reputable supplier.Big retailers like Home Depot and Lowes typically work directly with manufacturers approved by NIOSH or their distributors, so if you find an N95 mask in a major retail store you can be confident you’re getting the real thing. It’s a good idea to check manufacturer websites to see where they sell their products and who their authorized distributors are, Dr. McCullough said. 3M has a dedicated spot on its website to help consumers spot fake masks.Finding a reliable mask on Amazon is trickier because you’ll see legitimate masks mixed in with counterfeits, although the differences won’t always be obvious. If you must use Amazon, try to shop directly in the on-site stores of mask makers like 3M or Kimberly-Clark. (You can usually find a link to a maker’s online store right below a product name.)If you’re buying a KF94 on Amazon, look closely at the packaging to make sure it’s made in Korea and includes the required labeling (see below for more details). Aaron Collins, an engineer who routinely tests masks and who has gained a YouTube following as “Mask Nerd,” recommends buying KF94s from Korean beauty product importers like Be Healthy or KMact. Once you learn the names of a few KF94 manufacturers, you can try to find their websites to learn where they are sold. For instance, Happy Life lists its five U.S. distributors on its home page.You can sometimes find N95 and KN95 masks for sale directly on the website of a mask maker, like Demetech and Armbrust USA. You can also look for companies that are exclusive distributors of KN95 masks, like Bona Fide Masks. The nonprofit site Project N95 is also a reliable place to shop. Many trusted sites are overwhelmed by demand right now, so you may encounter delays in fulfillment and shipping times.Check labels and printing.Legitimate N95s and KN95s are required to have specific text stamped on the front of the mask. Although you may find one in a fun color, masks that are printed with fancy designs or don’t have text stamped on them are probably fake.Your N95 should be stamped with “NIOSH,” as well as the company name, the model and lot numbers, and something called a “TC approval” number, which can be used to look up the mask on a list of approved ones. The C.D.C. has created an infographic showing you the printing to look for on your N95.ImageCredit...Charlie Rubin for The New York TimesA legitimate KN95 should also be stamped with text, including the name of the manufacturer, the model, and “GB2626-2019,” which is a reference to a quality control standard approved by the Chinese government. (If your mask has a GB number that ends in 2006, which is a previous standard, just check the expiration date.)The KF94 won’t be stamped with text, but the package should say “Made in Korea” and include the product name, manufacturer and distributor name. Each mask should be packaged individually in a flat, glossy rectangular wrapper with a textured border. The package will also have an expiration date and a lot number printed on it. (Masks that carry an electrostatic charge all have expiration dates.) If your mask comes from a Korean importer, the information on the package will be in Korean, but many companies have begun to create English-language packaging.Use trusted sources.A number of resources have sprung up to help people navigate the mask-buying process. Project N95 is a nonprofit known for vetting its mask suppliers. Mr. Collins, the Mask Nerd, has created a number of lists and resources for mask buyers. You can check out his Twitter feed, his YouTube channel and a spreadsheet he has created of nearly 450 different masks and how they performed in his tests.Mr. Collins may be best known for his list of children’s masks. While there is no N95 mask for kids approved in the United States, mask makers in China and Korea have created KN95s and KF94s for children, including some with child-friendly colors and prints. Mr. Collins created a video “primer for parents” about finding a high-quality mask for kids that has more than 100,000 views.“I had retired from mask testing,” Mr. Collins said, noting that he doesn’t receive any compensation for his work. “But I came out of retirement to do the kids video. The only place I’ve seen a list of test data is unfortunately me.”Wirecutter, a product review site owned by The New York Times, has a guide for buying quality masks, one for buying children’s masks and a list of 12 red flags that might signal your mask is a counterfeit.Do your research.It’s not easy, but the C.D.C. has a few lists you can use to confirm a mask has been vetted. A note of caution: If you don’t find a particular mask, make sure you’ve looked it up the correct way, said Anne Miller, executive director of Project N95. For instance, a Gerson N95 mask won’t be found under the letter “G.” It’s listed under “L” because the full name of the company that makes it is Louis M. Gerson.For N95 masks, go to the C.D.C.’s alphabetical list of NIOSH-approved respirators. You can also look up the TC approval number using the certified equipment list.For KN95 masks, you can use two checklists from the Food and Drug Administration. The F.D.A. created these lists early in the pandemic, when the agency issued an emergency use authorization that allowed health workers to use KN95 masks because of a shortage of N95s. Now that the N95 supply is adequate, the agency has revoked the authorization for these workers, but other people can still use KN95s. While the list is now a bit outdated, finding your mask on it adds reassurance that it’s less likely to be counterfeit — with the caveat that there’s no longer official U.S. oversight for any of these firms. You’ll need to scroll down to find the list and search box.Use this F.D.A. list to find KN95 masks made in China, and this list for KN95 masks made in other countries.Jin Yu Young contributed to this report.
